abstract: <jats:p><jats:italic>Etainia thoraceleuca</jats:italic> van Nieukerken, Epstein & Davis, <jats:bold>sp. nov.</jats:bold> is the second native American species of <jats:italic>Etainia</jats:italic> Beirne, 1945, and the second known <jats:italic>Etainia</jats:italic> species feeding on Ericaceae. The species is known from light-collected adults in the USA (California, Arizona) and Canada (Ontario). These were linked via DNA barcodes to larvae that make short leafmines on <jats:italic>Arbutus</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>Arctostaphylos</jats:italic> species, then continue feeding in stems and branches, causing damage in nurseries and planted trees in Sonoma and Marin Counties, California. The holotype was accidentally reared from <jats:italic>Arbutus arizonica</jats:italic>, without observing the damage. Life history and damage are described in detail. Damage in <jats:italic>Arctostaphylos uva-ursi</jats:italic> found in Washington State probably belongs to <jats:italic>E. thoraceleuca</jats:italic>, which is a sister species to the European <jats:italic>E. albibimaculella</jats:italic> (Larsen, 1927).</jats:p>
title: A new North American species of Etainia (Lepidoptera, Nepticulidae), feeding on Arbutus and Arctostaphylos species (Ericaceae)
